projects.name: asciiPainter
projects.body: A TTY program for ASCII art, made with ncurses/PDCurses. This came out of my growing obsession with terminals and CLIs.

projects.name: 3D Renderer
projects.body: To solve the philosophical question of 'how do 3D graphics work,' I made a basic software renderer (with wonky texture support).

projects.name: Azur Lane Fleet Tech Tracker
projects.body: A tracker website for a specific feature in a weird game. Designed to be self-maintaining!

expertise.name: Angular
expertise.content:
Angular is my first frontend framework, which I learnt and used (alongside Ionic) throughout my first job and is my go-to for serious projects.

By the way, this site was made with it!

expertise.name: Ionic
expertise.content: A separate framework that can be used alongside Angular, Ionic is my go-to for mobile development and other useful stuff (UI components, CLI, capacitor plugins).

expertise.name: Dialogflow
expertise.content: For a prototype AI chatbot, I used Dialogfow to see if it would fit the bill. It ended up coming short due to some weird limitations, but it was fun to use for the time being and can work for simple chatbots (it was bad with dates, though).

expertise.name: Laravel
expertise.content: I learnt Laravel (and other relevant tech like PHP and MySQL) as the backend framework at Stampede, and can comfortably use it for small-scale projects, or prototypes.

expertise.name: Docker
expertise.content: Thanks to a PHP version conflict, I was introduced to Docker. In particular, I learnt to use Docker Compose for multi-container setups, and always prefer to use it for production.

expertise.name: Python
expertise.content: I use Python for quick scripts and prototypes, and sometimes save them.

expertise.name: C++
expertise.content:
My favourite langauge(s)!! Dealing with segfaults and leaking 3-dimensional pointers are my PASTIME!!!

On a serious note, C++ is my go-to for developing native apps that aren't for web.

expertise.name: CMake
expertise.content: I didn't want to deal with Visual Studio, so I found CMake as the defacto 'multi-platform' build system. When I transitioned to Mac, I stuck with it to develop asciiPainter as my first multi-platform project.

expertise.name: Go
expertise.content: After contributing to a project built with Go, I found it to be the best of many worlds between compiled language robustness and dynamic language simplicty. It has quickly become one of my favourite languages, and is a decent option when picking one for any project.

expertise.name: Linux
expertise.content: FOSS FTW! Aside from MacOS, I use Arch Linux as my main operating system. Occasionally I try out other Linux distrobutions, but Arch is what I always come back to. Maybe I'll try out BSD someday!
